I don't agree. A committed relationship involves knowing the other person, their issues, history, etc. You're going to have a better chance of knowing if the other person has an STD already. Casual sex is a crapshoot. You know little about the person, more than likely. Heck, there are even people out there who intentionally try to spread their STDs.

 The people out there who are purposely spreading STDs are rare. Either way, I agree with you that sex in a committed relationship is generally safer where STDs are concerned than sex outside a committed relationship. I think the consequences if one does get STDs are not that different but the original risk is smaller. How much smaller? That depends on how one practices the safe sex. I don't have the numbers, but if one practices sex responsibly, I think the risk of catching STDs is quite small. It may be higher for people who are truly promiscuous (lots of sex partners each year) but most people are not nearly that promiscuous.
 
With all due respect, if we've reduced the idea of "self-control" to little more than quickly putting on a condom, it's no wonder promiscuity is so commonplace. Sure, I guess you could call that "self-control" but I think that's pushing it. Nevertheless, I'm going to continue using the term in place of "abstinence" because of the connotations that "abstinence" carries these days. If you have another suggestion for a term, I welcome your ideas.

 What connotations does "abstinence" carry, in your view, that you disagree with? 
 
 Either way, I think "self-control" applies to any responsible behavior on the teenagers part. Of course, abstinence requires more self control but the self control needed to put on a condom or take contraception would go a long way toward reducing unwanted teenage pregnancies and abortions. I think that is a worthy goal.
 
I told you, my ultimate goal is to protect kids. How I'd change the culture is promote sound values like self-value, self-control, the importance of commitment and sticking to it, etc. All this is related. I believe that kids' values are being influenced very early on. And then there's the issue of the saturation of our market economy with sexual messages and visuals. I'd love to see more effort toward convincing companies to clean up their advertising. Maybe even with incentives, if necessary. 

 I would agree with most of that. Kids are influenced by media to grow up too quickly here. You even see ten year old girls dressing provocatively nowadays. What ever happened to innocent childhood? I agree that reducing sexual images will help. However, at some point, hormones really do kick in and effect teen's social tendencies toward sex. You have to prepare them with the proper tools to face that.
 
That's like saying we should just offer an alternative to not speeding called "controlled speeding," or learning to speed in a safe way. 

 I should note that in reality we have that. Nearly everyone speeds, but they are controlled by a combination of their fear of getting caught (where the rule of thumb, even as stated by police, is that going up to 10mph above is ok) and their own driving abilities in a wide range of weather, traffic, road and car conditions.
 
No, I don't think the selling points on protection are better than self-control--I think the problem is that self-control just doesn't have enough people pushing it. Think about it-- using protection means putting your life in the hands of a layer of latex, all for a cheap temporary thrill. There's that 1% chance of failure, and if you're the girl you're essentially trusting the guy completely if you let him use his own protection. 

 If you double up on protection, then the risk goes much farther down. Yes, there is a small risk no matter what contraceptive you use. Most teens are willing to take that risk for the thrill of sex. You are trying to convince them that the slight increase in safety is worth their huge sacrifice of not having sex. That is not an arguement that will convince a lot of teens. What other arguements do you have?
 
Again, for the 3rd time, you're pitting abstinence against safe-sex. This is a false dichotomy; BOTH can be taught. Both SHOULD be taught. I just think abstinence should be taught up front along with safe-sex as a safety net, because it sets a standard and if you only teach safe-sex or just put abstinence on as an afterthought, you run the risk of giving the idea that promiscuity is a normal and healthy way of life. It's not. It's a risky way of life.

 Once again, I am not saying that only one should be taught. I agree with you that both should be taught. However, I would concentrate on teaching about contraception, while also noting the benefits of abstinence - for you, it would be the other way around. As for promiscuity being a risky way of life, yes it is but it depends both on the degree of promiscuity and on the precautions (in contraception) used during sex. Perhaps I'm wrong, but I think that most teens who have sex are not having sex with a wide range of partners - just one, perhaps another the next year, etc.
 
 I would rather have a greater chance of reducing unwanted teen pregnancies by accepting the reality and teaching them to have sex responsibly than by trying to change their reality (which is much harder to do and has a high risk of failure). 
 
That way you have it covered. They know abstinence is best, but you've given then the knowledge and information they need for safe-sex too if they give in or intend not to exercise self-control.

 Agreed. We BOTH agree that both safe-sex and abstinence should be taught. However, teens have a minimal attention span. I am worried that if you concentrate more on abstinence, then you will loose too much of the teenage audience and they won't even be listening any more to the contraceptive part.
Master_Shake

Didn't actually think about it in that way. Though I would maintain that someone who is obviously unable to look after their existing kids, and having had several previous pregnancies and children and continued using drugs, shouldn't have the same rights over their own body when it comes to the choice of bringing a child into the world, as those who don't have the same risk factors to a child.

 What are the standards for determining who has a right over their own bodies then and who gets to determine them?
